query: Tell me about Indigenous land management in Brazi

nodes.label: land degradation
nodes.description: A negative trend in the condition of land, expressed as long-term reduction or loss of at least one of the following: biological productivity, ecological integrity or value to humans.

nodes.label: Ecological buffer zones
nodes.description: Buffer zones are designated areas used to protect sensitive landscape patches (e.g., wetlands, wildlife reserves) o lessen the impacts of human activity and land disturbance.

nodes.label: drought
nodes.description: A drought is an extended period of unusually dry weather marked by a significant and sustained lack of precipitation, falling below a specific threshold over a large area for more than a month

nodes.label: economic sector
nodes.description: Area of the economy in which actors engage in identical or related activities.

nodes.label: Control of sand encroachment
nodes.description: The fundamental principle of dune fixation is that of preventing sand from moving during a long enough period to allow natural or planted vegetation to become established. If sand encroachment is to be controlled, saltation must be reduced, either by stabilizing the soil or by reducing the wind speed gradient close to the surface of the ground.

nodes.label: Reduced impact logging
nodes.description: Logging techniques that result in significantly less damage to the surrounding forest and forest ecosystem. Examples of RIL include directional felling, trimming of inter-crown vines, and careful road planning.

nodes.label: climate-resilient forest management
nodes.description: Climate-Resilient Forest Management focuses on enhancing forest health to reduce risks associated with rising temperatures, shifting hydrological conditions, storms, fires, and pest outbreaks. It involves the diversification of trees' ages and species to reduce vulnerability.

nodes.label: Windbreaks
nodes.description: Windbreaks are linear plantings of trees and shrubs designed to provide economic, environmental and community benefits. The primary purpose of most windbreaks is to slow the wind which creates a more beneficial condition for soils, crops, livestock, wildlife and people.

nodes.label: timber production
nodes.description: activities involved in harvesting, processing, and distributing wood and wood-based products for construction, paper production, and other uses

nodes.label: submarine landslide
nodes.description: A submarine landslide is a downslope movement of sediment or rock under the effect of gravity, which occurs when the stresses acting downslope exceed the available strength of the sediment on the slope.

nodes.label: Soilless agriculture
nodes.description: Soilless agriculture refers to agricultural practices that grow plants without the use of traditional soil.

nodes.label: fishing sector
nodes.description: Activities involving the catching, processing, and selling of fish for food, recreation, and industry.

nodes.label: soil moisture monitoring
nodes.description: Soil moisture is the amount of water in the soil. It is linked to the water cycle and is affected by both weather and climate patterns. It is also a vital component of the overall composition of ecosystems, affecting biodiversity. Accurate monitoring of soil moisture is therefore essential for understanding and managing environmental and societal challenges such as agricultural dynamics and biodiversity monitoring.

nodes.label: Drought-resistant crops
nodes.description: Drought-resistant crops are varieties of plants that are specifically bred or naturally adapted to withstand prolonged periods of low water availability.

nodes.label: Forested catchments protection
nodes.description: Forested catchments protection refers to the practice of preserving and managing forested areas within a catchment (or watershed) to maintain the health and function of the entire ecosystem. A catchment is the area of land where all precipitation collects and drains into a common outlet, such as a river, lake, or reservoir.

nodes.label: wildfire
nodes.description: Wildfires are any unplanned or uncontrolled fire affecting natural, cultural, industrial and residential landscapes. Changing weather conditions associated with global warming increase the probability of wildfires.

nodes.label: desertification
nodes.description: Land degradation in arid, semi-arid and dry sub-humid areas (drylands) resulting from various factors, including climatic variations and human activities.

nodes.label: increasing temperatures
nodes.description: Earth's temperature has risen since 1850 due to human induced climate change. Increasing temperatures intensify the hydrologic cycle, causing dry regions to become drier and wet regions to become wetter.

nodes.label: agriculture sector
nodes.description: Activities that involve the cultivation of crops and raising of livestock for food, fibre, and other products essential for human life and industry.

nodes.label: Fungal symbioses
nodes.description: It is a symbiotic relationship between a fungus and a photosynthetic bacteria or algae. The cells from the alga or bacterium live inside the fungus. Besides providing a home, the fungus also provides nutrients. In turn, the bacterium or the alga provides energy to the fungus by performing photosynthesis.

nodes.label: plastic leaching
nodes.description: The process of when plastic elements contaminate its surrounding environment.

nodes.label: forest degradation
nodes.description: Land degradation in forested areas, referring to the loss of the biological wealth of a forest.

nodes.label: drought insurance
nodes.description: Drought insurance is a type of insurance that protects against losses caused by drought. Droughts can lead to losses for farmers.

nodes.label: landfilling
nodes.description: The process of depositing waste into or onto the land

nodes.label: Alternative sustainable feeds
nodes.description: Alternative sustainable feeds refer to non-traditional, environmentally friendly feed options for livestock that reduce the reliance on conventional grains and forages, which can be resource-intensive to produce.

nodes.label: agricultural insurance
nodes.description: Insurance has become even more important as extreme weather events and climate change have increased the risks and uncertainties of farmers and agriculture-based enterprises, creating the need for agricultural insurance to protect from losses.

nodes.label: crop diversification and new varieties
nodes.description: Crop diversification refers to the practice of growing a variety of different crops on the same agricultural land, rather than focusing on a single crop. This strategy is used to reduce the risks associated with farming, such as those caused by pests, diseases, or unpredictable weather patterns. It also helps improve soil health, increase biodiversity, and provide a more stable income for farmers.

nodes.label: biodiversity loss
nodes.description: Increasing air and water temperatures and altered precipitation patterns are affecting the structure, composition and functions of ecosystems. Resulting in loss of biodiversity that help support human well-being.

nodes.label: desert community
nodes.description: Communities that live in the desert

nodes.label: crop production
nodes.description: This area encompasses the cultivation of plants for food, feed, fibree, fuel, and other purposes. It involves activities like planting, growing, and harvesting a wide variety of crops.

nodes.label: Bushfire reduction
nodes.description: "Bushfire reduction" refers to efforts and strategies aimed at minimizing the risk, frequency, and severity of bushfires. One strategy is the 'firebreaks', which purpose is to prevent forest fires from spreading before they damage the ecosystem, cropland or personal property. It consists in creating cleared areas to stop or slow the spread of bushfires.

nodes.label: Biodiversity management systems
nodes.description: Biodiversity management systems (BMS) refer to organised frameworks or strategies designed to conserve and protect biodiversity in a given area, while also ensuring that human activities and development do not negatively impact ecosystems. These systems integrate environmental, social, and economic aspects to maintain or enhance biodiversity.

nodes.label: non-timber forest sector
nodes.description: Collection and use of forest resources other than timber, such as fruits, nuts, medicinal plants, resins, and fibres

nodes.label: sustainable development goal 15
nodes.description: SDG15: life on land

nodes.label: forestry
nodes.description: science and craft of creating, managing, using, conserving and repairing forests, woodlands, and associated resources for human and environmental benefits

nodes.label: reforestation
nodes.description: natural or intentional restocking of existing forests and woodlands that have been depleted

nodes.label: forestry sector
nodes.description: Activities that relate to the production of goods and services from forests.

nodes.label: mixed farming
nodes.description: Mixed farming combines crop and animal production on the same farm.

nodes.label: E-agriculture
nodes.description: e-Agriculture is a global community of practice that facilitates dialogue, information exchange and sharing of ideas related to the use of information and communication technologies (ICTs) for sustainable agriculture and rural development.

nodes.label: Adaptation technologies
nodes.description: Adaptation technologies are systems, tools, processes and innovations that facilitate the process of adjusting to and managing the current and future effects of climate change.

nodes.label: technologies
nodes.description: Human-created methods for extending agency.

nodes.label: extreme weather
nodes.description: Extreme weather refers to events where a weather variable exceeds (or falls below) a threshold. Meaning it is significantly different from the average or usual weather pattern.

nodes.label: sand encroachment
nodes.description: Sand encroachment occurs generally in arid to semi-arid regions when grains of sand are carried by winds and form sandy accumulation on coasts, along watercourses and on cultivated or uncultivated land causing major material and socioeconomic damage.

nodes.label: rural poor
nodes.description: people living outside of urban areas with limited assets or access to services

nodes.label: sustainable agriculture
nodes.description: Farming that meets the needs of existing and future generations, while also ensuring profitability, environmental health and social and economic equity.

nodes.label: Terracing
nodes.description: In agriculture, terracing refers to the technique of creating flat, stepped areas on slopes to facilitate farming. This method enhances water retention and reduces soil erosion, making it an essential practice in regions with hilly terrains.

nodes.label: informal sector
nodes.description: Households employing domestic workers, for activities like cooking, cleaning and subsistence farming, for their own use.

nodes.label: nitrous oxide
nodes.description: Nitrous oxide is a greenhouse gas 300 times more potent than carbon dioxide (CO2) that remains in the atmosphere for more than 100 years.

nodes.label: ammonia
nodes.description: An inorganic compound of nitrogen and hydrogen produced industrially as a fertilizer and for many other uses

nodes.label: forest protected area
nodes.description: Effective protection of tropical forests can reduce biodiversity loss and enhance carbon storage, as they are among the most biologically rich ecosystems on earth.

nodes.label: forest
nodes.description: A dense collection of trees covering a relatively large area

nodes.label: environmental remediation
nodes.description: and other waste management service activities

nodes.label: crop insurance
nodes.description: Agricultural producers can purchase crop insurance for protection against climate-related losses from extreme events like flooding, drought, and storms.

nodes.label: crop rotation
nodes.description: Crop rotation on arable land is the practice of alternating crops grown on a specific field in a planned pattern or sequence in successive crop years so that crops of the same species are not grown without interruption on the same field. In a rotation the crops are normally changed annually, but they can also be multi-annual.

nodes.label: Prescribed fire
nodes.description: Prescribed fire is a form of land management in which fire is intentionally applied to vegetation. Prescribed fires are conducted under desired conditions to meet specific objectives, such as to restore fire regimes in adapted ecosystems or to limit the amount of dry brush in an area prone to wildfires.

nodes.label: salinization
nodes.description: Increasing evaporation from rising temperatures leads to the salinization of soil and water. Salts accumulate in the soils of arid environments.

nodes.label: indigenous people
nodes.description: Social and cultural groups that share collective ancestral ties to the lands and natural resources where they live, occupy or from which they have been displaced

nodes.label: climate tolerant livestock
nodes.description: Climate-tolerant livestock refers to animals that are specifically bred or naturally adapted to withstand challenging environmental conditions caused by climate change.

nodes.label: Forest fire control
nodes.description: Fire Control is defined as all activities concerned with protection of the vegetative cover and structures from destruction by fire

nodes.label: Soil remediation
nodes.description: Soil remediation refers to the strategy of managing soil to control salinity and sodicity, in order to reduce plant stress and improve productivity. Another goal is to reduce contaminants concentration.

nodes.label: Integrated nutrient management
nodes.description: Integrated Nutrient Management refers to the maintenance of soil fertility and of plant nutrient supply at an optimum level for sustaining the desired productivity through optimization of the benefits from all possible sources of organic, inorganic and biological components in an integrated manner.

nodes.label: Indigenous water storage structures
nodes.description: Indigenous knowledge have developed over time by communities. It is a body of knowledge based on experience and not confined to tribal groups. Communities in arid and semi-arid areas have relied on indigenous knowledge to harvest rain water providing water as supplement, to increase crop yield and reduce the risk of crop failure. Indigenous RWH combine technical efficiency with low cost and acceptability to the local farmers.

nodes.label: deforestation
nodes.description: Removal of forest and conversion of the land to non-forest use, and is the direct human-induced conversion of forested land to non-forested land

nodes.label: afforestation
nodes.description: establishment of a forest or stand of trees in an area where there was no previous tree cover

nodes.label: biodiversity
nodes.description: The variability among living organisms from all sources and the ecological complexes of which they are part.

nodes.label: SDG target 2.b
nodes.description: Correct and prevent trade restrictions and distortions in world agricultural markets, including through the parallel elimination of all forms of agricultural export subsidies and all export measures with equivalent effect

nodes.label: sustainable development goal 2
nodes.description: SDG2: zero hunger

nodes.label: agricultural water management
nodes.description: planning and operation of water systems to supply water for agricultural purposes, including irrigation and livestock needs

nodes.label: pesticide
nodes.description: Pesticide means any substance, or mixture of substances of chemical or biological ingredients intended for repelling, destroying or controlling any pest, or regulating plant growth. Pesticides are inherently toxic.

nodes.label: animal production
nodes.description: Animal production involves raising livestock for meat, milk, eggs, wool, hides, and other animal products.
